contentrichtext.text: {{unreferenced|date=November 2011}} {{Infobox political party | party_name = National Liberal Party | native_name = حزب الوطنيين الأحرار<br>Ḥizb Al-Waṭaniyyīn Al-Aḥrār | party_logo = | leader = [[Dory Chamoun]] | founder = [[Camille Chamoun]] | foundation = 1958 | religion = Mainly [[Christianity|Christian]] | ideology = [[Liberalism]] | position = [[Centre-right]] | national = [[March 14 Alliance]] |affiliation1_title = Regional affiliation |affiliation1 = [[Arab Alliance for Freedom and Democracy]] | nationality = [[Lebanon|Lebanese]] | headquarters = Deir el Qamar | website = [http://www.ahrar.org.lb/ www.ahrar.org.lb] | colors = [[White]], [[red]], [[gold]] | colorcode = #B5121A | country = Lebanon }} The '''National Liberal Party''' (NLP, {{lang-ar|حزب الوطنيين الأحرار}}, literally ''Ḥizb Al-Waṭaniyyīn Al-Aḥrār'') is a [[center-right]] [[political party]] in [[Lebanon]], established by [[President of Lebanon|President]] [[Camille Chamoun]] in 1958. It is now under the leadership of [[Dory Chamoun]], his son. ==Policies== The party has adopted a hard line in regard to the preservation of Lebanese [[independence]], and to the safeguard of the distinctive [[Liberalism|liberal]] practices in Lebanon with respect to [[freedom of expression]] and [[freedom of speech|opinion]] and [[religious freedom]]s. Like most Lebanese political organization, it has a sectarian basis; the NLP is mainly supported by [[Christian]]s. (For more information on this, see [[Demographics of Lebanon]]) ==History== In 1968, the party joined The [[Helf Alliance]] formed with the two other big mainly [[Christian]] parties in Lebanon: the [[Kataeb]] of [[Pierre Gemayel]], and [[Lebanese National Bloc|National Bloc]] of [[Raymond Eddé]]. During the [[Lebanese Civil War]] of 1975-90, the NLP was aligned with the mainly [[Maronite]] [[Christian]] alliance who fought the [[Lebanese National Movement]] (LNM). It had its own armed militia, the [[Tigers Militia (Lebanon)|Tigers]]. In 1976, the NLP joined with the [[Kataeb Party]] (Phalange) and the [[Lebanese Renewal Party]] (LRP) to form the [[Lebanese Front]], a political coalition. This was paralleled by the joining of the militias under a central command, the [[Lebanese Forces]], headed by Phalange leader [[Bashir Gemayel]]. In 1980, Gemayel turned on the Tigers, and in a [[Day of the Long Knives (Beirut)|surprise attack in Safra]] eliminated the militia. The NLP has survived as a party, however. Nevertheless, with the death of [[Camille Chamoun]] in 1987 and the assassination of his successor and son [[Dany Chamoun|Dany]] in 1990, combined with the rise of the [[Lebanese Forces]] as political party, it seems that the NLP's political influence has considerably declined comparing to the 1960s and 1970s. In 2005 the NLP was part of the [[Qornet Shehwan Gathering]], opposed to the [[Syrian occupation of Lebanon]], but later left because of what it alleged was "corruption" in this gathering. ==External links== * [http://www.ahrar.org.lb/ Official Web Site] {{Lebanese political parties}} {{Interlib}} [[Category:March 14 alliance]] [[Category:Conservative-liberal parties]] [[Category:Liberal-conservative parties]] [[Category:Christian democratic parties]] [[Category:Political parties in Lebanon]] [[Category:Political parties established in 1958]] [[Category:Lebanese Front]] {{lebanon-party-stub}} {{liberalparty-stub}}
